question.title: Calculate size of Object in Java

node.contents: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/52353/in-java-what-is-the-best-way-to-determine-the-size-of-an-object

astNode.text: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/52353/in-java-what-is-the-best-way-to-determine-the-size-of-an-object

node.contents: You may want to try the totalMemory() and then freeMemory() and subtract those instead.

astNode.text: You may want to try the totalMemory() and then freeMemory() and subtract those instead.

node.contents: I want to record how much memory (in bytes, hopefully) an object takes up for a project (I'm comparing sizes of data structures) and it seems like there is no method to do this in Java. Supposedly, C/C++ has sizeOf() method, but this is nonexistant in Java. I tried recording the free memory in the JVM with Runtime.getRuntime().freeMemory() before and after creating the object and then recording the difference, but it would only give 0 or 131304, and nothing in between, regardless of the number of elements in the structure. Help please!

astNode.text: I want to record how much memory (in bytes, hopefully) an object takes up for a project (I'm comparing sizes of data structures) and it seems like there is no method to do this in Java. Supposedly, C/C++ has sizeOf() method, but this is nonexistant in Java. I tried recording the free memory in the JVM with Runtime.getRuntime().freeMemory() before and after creating the object and then recording the difference, but it would only give 0 or 131304, and nothing in between, regardless of the number of elements in the structure. Help please!

node.contents: The java.lang.instrument.Instrumentation class provides a nice way to get the size of a Java Object, but it requires you to define a premain and run your program with a java agent. This is very boring when you do not need any agent and then you have to provide a dummy Jar agent to your application.

astNode.text: The java.lang.instrument.Instrumentation class provides a nice way to get the size of a Java Object, but it requires you to define a premain and run your program with a java agent. This is very boring when you do not need any agent and then you have to provide a dummy Jar agent to your application.

node.contents: So I got an alternative solution using the Unsafe class from the sun.misc. So, considering the objects heap alignment according to the processor architecture and calculating the maximum field offset, you can measure the size of a Java Object. In the example below I use an auxiliary class UtilUnsafe to get a reference to the sun.misc.Unsafe object.

astNode.text: So I got an alternative solution using the Unsafe class from the sun.misc. So, considering the objects heap alignment according to the processor architecture and calculating the maximum field offset, you can measure the size of a Java Object. In the example below I use an auxiliary class UtilUnsafe to get a reference to the sun.misc.Unsafe object.

elements.contents: private static final int NR_BITS = Integer.valueOf(System.getProperty("sun.arch.data.model")); private static final int BYTE = 8; private static final int WORD = NR_BITS/BYTE; private static final int MIN_SIZE = 16; public static int sizeOf(Class src){ // // Get the instance fields of src class // List<Field> instanceFields = new LinkedList<Field>(); do{ if(src == Object.class) return MIN_SIZE; for (Field f : src.getDeclaredFields()) { if((f.getModifiers() & Modifier.STATIC) == 0){ instanceFields.add(f); } } src = src.getSuperclass(); }while(instanceFields.isEmpty()); // // Get the field with the maximum offset // long maxOffset = 0; for (Field f : instanceFields) { long offset = UtilUnsafe.UNSAFE.objectFieldOffset(f); if(offset > maxOffset) maxOffset = offset; } return (((int)maxOffset/WORD) + 1)*WORD; } class UtilUnsafe { public static final sun.misc.Unsafe UNSAFE; static { Object theUnsafe = null; Exception exception = null; try { Class<?> uc = Class.forName("sun.misc.Unsafe"); Field f = uc.getDeclaredField("theUnsafe"); f.setAccessible(true); theUnsafe = f.get(uc); } catch (Exception e) { exception = e; } UNSAFE = (sun.misc.Unsafe) theUnsafe; if (UNSAFE == null) throw new Error("Could not obtain access to sun.misc.Unsafe", exception); } private UtilUnsafe() { } }

comments.text: // // Get the instance fields of src class // List<Field> instanceFields = new LinkedList<Field>(); do{ if(src == Object.class) return MIN_SIZE; for (Field f : src.getDeclaredFields()) { if((f.getModifiers() & Modifier.STATIC) == 0){ instanceFields.add(f); } } src = src.getSuperclass(); }while(instanceFields.isEmpty()); // // Get the field with the maximum offset // long maxOffset = 0; for (Field f : instanceFields) { long offset = UtilUnsafe.UNSAFE.objectFieldOffset(f); if(offset > maxOffset) maxOffset = offset; } return (((int)maxOffset/WORD) + 1)*WORD; } class UtilUnsafe { public static final sun.misc.Unsafe UNSAFE; static { Object theUnsafe = null; Exception exception = null; try { Class<?> uc = Class.forName("sun.misc.Unsafe"); Field f = uc.getDeclaredField("theUnsafe"); f.setAccessible(true); theUnsafe = f.get(uc); } catch (Exception e) { exception = e; } UNSAFE = (sun.misc.Unsafe) theUnsafe; if (UNSAFE == null) throw new Error("Could not obtain access to sun.misc.Unsafe", exception); } private UtilUnsafe() { } }

node.contents: A google search of "Java sizeof" resulted in an nice article about Java sizeof on javaworld. Actually, an interesting read.

astNode.text: A google search of "Java sizeof" resulted in an nice article about Java sizeof on javaworld. Actually, an interesting read.

node.contents: To answer your question, there's not a Java equivalent of "sizeof()", but the article describes a couple of ways you can go about getting the byte size of your instantiated classes.

astNode.text: To answer your question, there's not a Java equivalent of "sizeof()", but the article describes a couple of ways you can go about getting the byte size of your instantiated classes.

node.contents: I recommend you taking a look at Jbellis JAMM. (https://github.com/jbellis/jamm) It relies on the instrumentation agent mentioned above but encapsulates some hepful utilities to deep measure the footprint of an entire object-graph. Looks simple and pretty cool to me.

astNode.text: I recommend you taking a look at Jbellis JAMM. (https://github.com/jbellis/jamm) It relies on the instrumentation agent mentioned above but encapsulates some hepful utilities to deep measure the footprint of an entire object-graph. Looks simple and pretty cool to me.

node.contents: Says "The only way to access an instance of the Instrumentation interface is for the JVM to be launched in a way that indicates the agent class - see the package specification. The Instrumentation instance is passed to the premain method of the agent class. Once an agent acquires the Instrumentation instance, the agent may call methods on the instance at any time. " <-- how do I do that (in Eclipse)?

astNode.text: Says "The only way to access an instance of the Instrumentation interface is for the JVM to be launched in a way that indicates the agent class - see the package specification. The Instrumentation instance is passed to the premain method of the agent class. Once an agent acquires the Instrumentation instance, the agent may call methods on the instance at any time. " <-- how do I do that (in Eclipse)?

node.contents: It has a method that can be used to get the implementation specific approximation of object size, as well as overhead associated with the object.

astNode.text: It has a method that can be used to get the implementation specific approximation of object size, as well as overhead associated with the object.

node.contents: The answer that Sergey linked has a great example, which I'll repost here, but you should have already looked at from his comment:

astNode.text: The answer that Sergey linked has a great example, which I'll repost here, but you should have already looked at from his comment:

elements.contents: import java.lang.instrument.Instrumentation; public class ObjectSizeFetcher { private static Instrumentation instrumentation; public static void premain(String args, Instrumentation inst) { instrumentation = inst; } public static long getObjectSize(Object o) { return instrumentation.getObjectSize(o); } }

units.rawText: import java.lang.instrument.Instrumentation; public class ObjectSizeFetcher { private static Instrumentation instrumentation; public static void premain(String args, Instrumentation inst) { instrumentation = inst; } public static long getObjectSize(Object o) { return instrumentation.getObjectSize(o); } }

node.contents: Use getObjectSize:

astNode.text: Use getObjectSize:

elements.contents: public class C { private int x; private int y; public static void main(String [] args) { System.out.println(ObjectSizeFetcher.getObjectSize(new C())); } }

units.rawText: public class C { private int x; private int y; public static void main(String [] args) { System.out.println(ObjectSizeFetcher.getObjectSize(new C())); } }

node.contents: @LouisWasserman if I am getting an output of Footprint{Objects=40004, References=92773, Primitives=[int x 40004, float]}, what is the total size?

astNode.text: @LouisWasserman if I am getting an output of Footprint{Objects=40004, References=92773, Primitives=[int x 40004, float]}, what is the total size?

node.contents: That varies depending on your JVM. If you want to measure bytes, then you should be using `MemoryMeasurer` from the same project; follow the instructions there.

astNode.text: That varies depending on your JVM. If you want to measure bytes, then you should be using `MemoryMeasurer` from the same project; follow the instructions there.

node.contents: @LouisWasserman If I use 64 bit JVM, can you tell me how to do the calculations?

astNode.text: @LouisWasserman If I use 64 bit JVM, can you tell me how to do the calculations?

node.contents: You need to know if CompressedOops is on, but in that case you should assume an Object has a 12 byte overhead, and that references, ints, and floats each take 4 bytes.

astNode.text: You need to know if CompressedOops is on, but in that case you should assume an Object has a 12 byte overhead, and that references, ints, and floats each take 4 bytes.

node.contents: Look into http://code.google.com/p/memory-measurer/. Guava uses it internally, and ObjectGraphMeasurer is especially straightforward to use out-of-the-box, without any special command-line arguments.

astNode.text: Look into http://code.google.com/p/memory-measurer/. Guava uses it internally, and ObjectGraphMeasurer is especially straightforward to use out-of-the-box, without any special command-line arguments.

elements.contents: import objectexplorer.ObjectGraphMeasurer; public class Measurer { public static void main(String[] args) { Set<Integer> hashset = new HashSet<Integer>(); Random rng = new Random(); int n = 10000; for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) { hashset.add(random.nextInt()); } System.out.println(ObjectGraphMeasurer.measure(hashset)); } }

units.rawText: import objectexplorer.ObjectGraphMeasurer; public class Measurer { public static void main(String[] args) { Set<Integer> hashset = new HashSet<Integer>(); Random rng = new Random(); int n = 10000; for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) { hashset.add(random.nextInt()); } System.out.println(ObjectGraphMeasurer.measure(hashset)); } }
